list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Below shows a Sankey diagram for an LED.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/32db4f78-02b8-43c8-82fb-6de54d482356/images/0cc12eab-6d49-485c-82a5-a201da16c116/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.58.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


Which of the following shows the percentage efficiency of the LED and the total power input?

Percentage efficiencyTotal power input$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $40\%$ $4$ W$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $40\%$ $20$ W$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $60\%$ $4$ W$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $60\%$ $20$ W
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Total power unput = total power output = $12\ +\ 8\ =\ 20$ W
For an LED useful energy is visible light energy:
Percentage efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{ Useful energy output}}{\textrm{ Total energy input}}\ (100)\ =\ \dfrac{8}{20}\ (100)\ =\ 40\%$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Which of the following units is not a unit of power?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ W
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ J
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ N m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ J s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The SI unit of power is W and it is defined as J s$^{-1}$.
Additionally, power can be calculated by


- $P = Fv$

When units of force and speed are substituted in the equation, the units become
$\hspace{1.5em}$ N m s$^{-1}$
But J is the SI unit of energy.
Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A builder uses a block and tackle pulley system to lift a bundle of materials of mass 15 kg to the top of a building of height 6 m in 9 s. What is the power delivered to the bundle? Assume $g=10$ N kg$^{-1}$.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d1489c-8ba8-4cb6-8d7b-fe039bac7303/images/94315b8c-73e2-407b-bd29-9b312cbeeda6/PH0125.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Image Source: Block-and-tackle-in-use.svg by Themightyquill licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0}]}$



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 W
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 17 W
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 100 W
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 900 W
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\begin{aligned}
\textrm{Power} &= \dfrac{mgh}{t}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&= \dfrac{(15\textrm{ kg})(6\textrm{ m})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})}{9\textrm{ s}}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
 &= 100\textrm{ W}\
 \end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The figure below shows a Sankey diagram for a small thermal plant. What is the efficiency of the system?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59cbaf81-366a-4d3b-84b4-81c19240c4a5/images/2e6829ac-2af0-4764-a71e-8c91dc895927/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%201.58.29%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 10%
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 20%
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 40%
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 60%
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In Sankey diagrams for energy, useful energy is shown as continuing straight while energy losses point downwards.
From the Sankey diagram, subtracting the value of the heat losses gives
To find the useful power:


- $1600 - (320 + 640) = 640$ kW

Efficiency can now be calculated:
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em}\eta &= \frac{\textrm{Useful power out}}{\textrm{Total power in}} \times 100\\
\hspace{1em}\\
&= \frac{640\textrm{ kW}}{1600\textrm{ kW}} \times 100\% \\
\hspace{1em}\\
&= 40\%
\end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
An object of mass $M$ on a string moves in a circle of radius $r$ at a constant speed.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6590a45d-55a7-400f-b7b5-4f31b825e7ad/images/ab24556d-04d2-418a-b7f4-9e1ca037a3f1/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.28.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)



Below are three statements about the motion of the object:


- I. $\hspace{1.1em}$ The resultant work done on the object is zero.
- II. $\hspace{0.8em}$ The velocity of the object is constant.
- III. $\hspace{0.5em}$ The object is accelerating

Which of the statements is/are true?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
I is correct. 
The accelerating force is always perpendicular to the direction of motion, therefore no work is done.


- $W = Fs \cos\theta$, and $\theta$ is always 90$\degree$, and $\cos 90 \degree =0$

Also, $W=\Delta E_k$ and the speed of the object is constant so there is no change in kinetic energy.
II is incorrect. 
Because velocity is a vector quantity and the direction is constantly changing, velocity is not constant.
III is correct. 
Because velocity is constantly changing, the object is always accelerating.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
A box is pulled by a child with a horizontal force of 5 N. The box moves a horizontal distance of 4 m in a time of 2 s. What is the average power delivered by the child to the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2.5 W
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5.0 W
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 W
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 40 W
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Power = $\dfrac{\Delta W}{t}$ and $W = Fs$


- $W = (5\ \ce{ N})(4\ \ce{m}) = 20$ J
- $P=\dfrac{20\textrm{ J}}{2\textrm{ s}} = 10$ W


Alternative:


- $P_{av} = Fv_{av} = F\bigg(\dfrac{\textrm{s}}{\textrm{t}}\bigg) = 5\bigg(\dfrac{4}{2}\bigg) = 10$ W

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Which of the following is not appropriate for measuring energy?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ J
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ N m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ kg m s$^{-2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ kg m$^{2}$ s$^{-2}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
A. J (joule) is an accepted unit of energy
B. Can be shown to represent energy using the work formula:  $W=Fs$ ; in terms of units, 1 J = 1  N m
C. Can analysed using Newton's Second Law $F=ma$; in terms of units, 1 N = 1 kg m s$^{-2}$. This is a unit of force not a unit of energy and therefore the $\underline{\textrm{correct}}$ answer.
D. Can be shown to represent energy using work and Newton's Second Law: $W = Fs = mas$; In terms of units,
J = N m = kg m s$^{-2}$ m = kg m$^{2}$ s$^{-2}$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The Sankey diagram below shows the energy degraded at different stages of a nuclear power plant.
Which of the following sections corresponds to the stage with the highest energy degradation?

B

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of $1.5$ m above the ground. What is the maximum height reached above the ground if the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s$^{-1}$?  (Take $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$)


- A. $\hspace{1em} 0.45$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em} 1.50$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em} 1.95$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em} 6.00$ m
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1: 
Maximum height occurs when the final speed $v$ is zero. The height reached above hand


- $\begin{aligned}
  \ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
  \ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
  \ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
  \end{aligned}$

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

Solution 2: 
Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion


- $\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh$
- $\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h$
- $h=0.45$ m

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

list.title: Question 10
list.content: - State the law of conservation of momentum. [2] - A stationary body explodes into two pieces of mass as $m_1$ and $m_2$ in opposite directions. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/429bf6fe-dca5-47bd-b7e0-b199cab3baa5/images/eb3d1823-146c-4af3-9a6b-1e4afd9aafe7/PH0463.png) Just after the explosion, the ratio of the kinetic energy of $m_1$ to the kinetic energy of $m_2$ is found to be 9. Calculate the ratio of masses $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- When the net force on a system is zero / the system is isolated $\checkmark$
  The momentum of the system does not change / the total momentum is constant $\checkmark$



- The magnitude of the momentum of the pieces is equal $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $\ll \dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9 \gg$
  - $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}\,\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Since the body is at rest, the total momentum before the explosion is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, total momentum after the collision must be zero. The two pieces move in the opposite directions. Therefore, the magnitude of momentum they possess must be the same to cancel each other. The ratio of kinetic energies;
  
  
  - $\dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9$
  - $\dfrac{m_2}{m_1} = 9$

  Therefore,
  
  
  - $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
A spring with spring constant $k$ is extended by a distance $x$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/75c10d0f-876b-4ad3-8025-7af70691d5b7/images/b7cb87cb-4bf9-4e63-9b30-1a5a397b29ca/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.19.25%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


$\small{\textrm{[Created using Geogebra https://www.geogebra.org/m/vUK7gGkN]}}$
The uncertainty of $k$ is 2% and that of $x$ is 3%.
What is the uncertainty of the potential energy stored in the spring?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 8%
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 11%
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 12%
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 18%
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The formula for potential energy stored is


- $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2$

Since $E_H$ is calculated from multiplying $k$ and $x^2$ (ignoring the constant $\frac{1}{2}$ as there is no uncertainty for it), then the uncertainty of $E_H$ is calculated by adding the fractional uncertainties of $x^2$ and $k$.
The fractional uncertainty of $x^2$ is double the fractional uncertainty on $x$, which gives


- $2\times3\% = 6\%$

The uncertainty of $E_P$ therefore


- 2% + 6% = 8%

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
A box of mass $m$ is pulled across a horizontal surface with a force $F$ as shown in the diagram. The coefficient of dynamic friction between the box and the surface is $\mu$. What is the energy transferred to thermal energy while a box is moved by a distance of $d$?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d68b186d-1f20-40cd-babc-b130ca4c968e/images/195ea83c-ec2e-42af-aa16-8f5e1a02e01e/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.10.31%E2%80%AFAM2.JPEG)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $Fd$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $(F-\mu mg)d$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\mu mgd$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $mgd$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Energy transferred to thermal energy will be the work done by the frictional force.


- $F_F=\mu F_N = \mu mg$  (where $F_N=mg$)
- $W = Fs = \mu mgd$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
A block of mass 16 kg is pushed and released along a rough horizontal surface at an initial speed of 2 m s$^{-1}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c45a6b1-fd52-47f4-87cf-51ddb2c7383c/images/0f148f8c-b290-441d-943e-e1bc0eba3a33/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.30.42%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The block travels through a distance of 16 m and is brought to rest. What is the magnitude of the frictional force that brings the block to rest?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2 N
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 4 N
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 8 N
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 16 N
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The net work done on the block 
= Change in kinetic energy of the block
$\begin{aligned}
 W_{net}&=\Delta E_k \\
 \hspace{1em}\\
 Fs \cos(\theta)& = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f)^2 - \frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\Fs\cos(\theta) &= 0 -\frac{1}{2}m(v_i)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(\cos\,180^o)&=-\frac{1}{2}(16)(2)^2 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
(F)(16)(-1)&=-32 \\
\hspace{1em}\\
F&=2\textrm{ N}\
\end{aligned}$
Alternative:


- $v^2 = u^2 + 2as \Rightarrow a = \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2s} = \dfrac{0^2 - 2^2}{2(16)} = -0.125$ m s$^{-2}$
- $|F| = m|a| = 16|-0.125| = 2$ N

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The engine of a racing  car provides a forward thrust of 800 N. The average of the total resistive forces acting on the car is 300 N and the car covers a distance of 1.0 km in 10 s.
What is the average power input of the engine?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^3$ W
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	8.0\times{10}^3$ W
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	5.0\times{10}^4$ W

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
An electric motor is used to raise a block of mass 18.0 kg vertically to the top of a building at a constant speed of 1.5 m s$^{-1}$. If the power rating of the motor is 297 W, calculate the efficiency of the motor. Assume $g=10$ N kg$^{-1}$.


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 9%
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 75%
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 61%
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 91%
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Efficiency is the ratio of power output to power input expressed as a percentage.


- $P_{input} = 297$ W
- Force = $mg = (18\textrm{ kg})(10\textrm{ N kg}^{-1})= 180$ N
- $P_{output}$ = (Force)(Velocity) = $\dfrac{(180\textrm{ N})(1.50\textrm{ m})}{1\textrm{ s}}$ = 270 W
- $Efficiency=\dfrac{Power\,output}{Power\,input} \times 100$
- $ \eta = \dfrac{270\,\ce{W}}{297\,\ce{W}}\,\times$ 100% = 91%

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
An object of mass $2$ kg with initial kinetic energy $10$ J comes to rest as it travels a distance of $3$ m along a flat horizontal rough surface as shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/efa48de6-a923-458e-b5b0-b3f399753505/images/08aa8a00-e6f6-44bc-a347-3dcafca9cf08/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2011.38.35%E2%80%AFAM.png)


What is the coefficient of dynamic friction between the object and the surface?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{6}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2}{3}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
Kinetic energy is transferred to work done (by friction)


- $\Delta E_K = F_f s = (\mu F_N)s =(\mu_dmg)s$

Substituting the given values leads to


- $10 = \mu_d(2)(10)(3)$
- $1 = \mu_d(2)(3)$
- $\mu_d = \dfrac{1}{6}$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
A box is pulled up a slope inclined at 30° to the horizontal by a force of $F$. The angle between the direction of $F$ and the plane of the incline is also 30°.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f7c7fada-3e7a-40ef-8afc-46a456e898cb/images/73fc01a0-5e0f-4607-82ff-a8c692a1b23d/PH0571.png)


The box is pulled a distance of d up along the slope. What is the work done by F on the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\cos(30°) $
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\cos(60°) $
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\sin(30°) $
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\cos^2(30°) $
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The component of the force parallel to the slope can be expressed as


- $F_p=F\cos(30°)$

The work done $W$ is the product of the force $F_p$ in the direction of motion and distance $d$.


- $W=F_pd$
- $W=F\cos(30°) d=Fd\cos(30°)$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: A spring of mass m is compressed against a block of mass $2m$ on a frictionless surface. The system is held stationary and the elastic potential energy stored in spring is $E_H$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04be70e3-9fb6-45cf-81d3-0066e5826298/images/ae44405c-172d-46c3-9b47-ee19e589be98/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.31.08%E2%80%AFAM.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}$ The system is released and the block and spring move horizontally. All of the elastic potential energy of the spring is converted into kinetic energy of the system. - - Show that after the system is released, the speed of the block $v_b$ is given by the equation: - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}$ [3] - The following data are given: - Mass of spring $m=120$ g - Spring constant of spring $k=85$ N m$^{-2}$ - Initial compression of the spring $x=8.0$ cm Calculate $v_b$. [2] - - The block moves onto a surface where the coefficient of dynamic friction between the block and the ground is $\mu_d=0.07$. When the block is at point $A$ its velocity is $0.71$ m s$^{-1}$. The block comes at a complete stop at point $B$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04be70e3-9fb6-45cf-81d3-0066e5826298/images/1e747ed3-6739-44b6-a508-87c8724e142b/Screenshoot%202025-06-04%20at%209.29.42%E2%80%AFAM.png) Determine the distance between $A$ and $B$. [3] - It is observed that the force required to start the block moving again is greater than the force required to keep it moving at a constant speed. Explain this observation. [1]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Conservation of energy:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2_s+\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)(v_b)^2$ $\checkmark$

    Conservation of momentum:
    
    
    - $2mv_b=mv_s$ $\checkmark$

    Correct substitution and rearranging for $v_b$:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(2v_b)^2+\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)(v_b)^2$
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(6v_b)^2$
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Due to the conservation of energy, we have:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}mv_s^2+\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)(v_b)^2$
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(v_s^2+2v_b^2)$

    The initial momentum of the system is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, the magnitudes of the the two momenta will be equal:
    
    
    - $2mv_b=mv_s$
    - $2v_b=v_s$

    (working with (scalar) speeds $v_s$ and $v_b$ rather than (vector) velocities)
    Combining these equations we have:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m((2v_b)^2+2v_b^2)$
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}m(6v_b^2)$
    - $E_H=3m(v_b)^2$
    - $(v_b)^2=\dfrac{E_H}{3m}$
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{E_H}{3m}}$

    
  - 
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(85)(0.080)^2\ll=0.272\gg$ $\checkmark$
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{0.272}{3(0.12)}}=$ 0.87 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Elastic potential energy $E_H$ is given by:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2$

    Where $k$ is the spring constant and $x$ is the extension or compression of the spring.
    Substituting in our values gives:
    
    
    - $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta x)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(85)(0.08)^2=0.272$ J

    Now substituting these values into the equation given in part (a)(i) we have:
    
    
    - $v_b=\sqrt{\dfrac{0.272}{3(0.12)}}=0.87$ m s$^{-1}$

    

- 
  - 
    
    - $a=\ll-\gg\dfrac{\mu_dmg}{m}=\ll-\gg(0.07)(9.81)=\ll-\gg0.687$ m s$^{-2}$ (3sf) $\checkmark$
    - $s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37$ m $\checkmark$
    - OR

    
    
    - $\mu_dmgs=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$ $\checkmark$
    - $s=\dfrac{0.71^2}{2(0.687)}=$ $0.37$ m $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The net force acting on the block is equal to the frictional force given by:
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu_dF_N$

    Where $\mu_d$ is the coefficient of dynamic friction and $F_N$ is the normal reaction force.
    The net vertical force is zero so the normal reaction force acting on the block is equal to its weight:
    
    
    - $F_N=mg$
    - $F_f=\mu_dmg$

    Net force:
    
    
    - $F_{net}=ma$

    Where $m$ is the mass of the block and $a$ is its acceleration. The net force on the block is negative as it acts in the opposite direction to the block's velocity:
    
    
    - $ma=-\mu_dmg$
    - $a=-\mu_dg$
    - $a=-(0.07)(9.81)=-0.6867$ m s$^{-2}$

    Now for constant acceleration we have:
    
    
    - $v^2=u^2+2as$

    Where $v$ is final velocity, $u$ is initial velocity, $a$ is acceleration and $s$ is displacement. Rearranging for $s$ and substituting our values we have:
    
    
    - $v^2-u^2=2as$
    - $s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37$ m

    Alternatively, we can use conservation of energy. The block loses all its kinetic energy due to work done by friction.
    Work done by friction is given by:
    
    
    - $W = Fs$

    And the force of friction can be found from:
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu_dF_N$
    - $F_N=mg$
    - $F_f=\mu_dmg$

    Equating the change in kinetic energy to the work done by friction gives:
    
    
    - $\mu_dmgs=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$

    Solving for $s$ leads to the same equation as the other solution:
    
    
    - $s=\dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a}=\dfrac{0^2-0.71^2}{2(-0.687)}=0.37$ m

    
  - coefficient of static friction/ maximum static frictional force is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction/dynamic frictional force. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When an object is already in motion, the dynamic frictional force opposes its motion and remains constant. However, when the object is at rest, the static frictional force prevents it from moving.
    Static friction can take any value up to its maximum limit, which is given by:
    
    
    - $F_f=\mu_sF_N$

    where $\mu_s$ is the coefficient of static friction and $F_N$ is the normal reaction force.
    The coefficient of static friction is greater than the coefficient of dynamic friction, so the maximum static frictional force is also greater than the dynamic frictional force. This means that more force is required to start on object moving from rest than is required to keep it moving at a constant speed against a dynamic frictional force.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: - A ball of mass $0.20$ kg moving on a frictionless horizontal plane collides elastically with a vertical wall. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/53468848-1041-4735-9efe-c31aa4376dbd/images/2895dd52-b8a7-4f2a-8e01-1d5ff5c6a617/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.32.51%E2%80%AFPM.png) The variation of the force $F$ acting on the ball during the collision with time $t$ is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/53468848-1041-4735-9efe-c31aa4376dbd/images/670df608-825b-4b06-9083-411840c17cbf/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.13.31%E2%80%AFPM.png) The speed of the ball just before the impact is $5.0$ m s$^{-1}$. Calculate the maximum force exerted on the wall by the ball. [3] - The wall is covered with a coating that causes an inelastic collision. The ball hits the wall with the same initial speed and bounces back with a speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$. - Explain, by considering the moments just before and after the collision, how the principle of conservation of energy applies to the collision. [2] - Calculate the loss of the energy of the ball during the collision. [2] - During this collision, the ball undergoes a change in momentum. Discuss whether the the law of conservation of momentum applies in this situation. [2]
list.markScheme:

  $\hspace{2em}$ $F_{max}=\dfrac{(2.0)(2)}{(10\times{10}^{-3})}=400$ N
  
- 
  - Loss of kinetic energy of the ball $\checkmark$
Equals to the increase in internal energy of the objects and surroundings $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The law of conservation of energy states that in any interaction, energy is not created or destroyed. In this situation, although the ball loses kinetic energy overall, this energy is transferred to thermal energy in the surroundings during the collision.
    
  - $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{Ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(5.0\right)^2=2.5$ J
    and
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{Kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(3.0\right)^2=0.9$ J $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
A camping stove uses fuel for cooking food in a pot. The fuel has an energy density of $u\,\ce{J m}^{-3}$, and the volume of fuel consumed is $V$ m$^3$. The energy transferred from the fuel to the cooking pot is $E\,$J.
What is the efficiency of the cooking stove?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{EV}{u}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{u}{EV}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{E}{uV}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{uV}{E}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- Energy density = $\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}$

The energy $E_F$ provided by the fuel (total energy in):


- $E_F = \textrm{Energy density}\times\textrm{Volume}$
- $E_F=uV$

The efficiency $\eta$ of the stove:


- $\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{Useful energy out}}{\textrm{Total energy in}}=\dfrac{E}{uV}$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
A spring that obeys Hooke's Law is stretched a distance $x$ and stores energy $E$.
What is the work done by the spring when it returns to the point where $x$ is reduced to half of its original value?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{E}{4}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{E}{2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{3E}{4}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $2E$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The energy of a stretched spring is given by
$\hspace{1em}$ $E=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2$
When the stretched length is halved, the final energy is
$\hspace{1em}$ $E_f=\dfrac{1}{2}k\left(\dfrac{x}{2}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{4} \left(\dfrac{1}{2} kx^2 \right) = \dfrac{1}{4}E$
The work done is given by
$\hspace{1em}$ $W=\Delta E$
$\hspace{1em}$ $W=E - \dfrac{1}{4}E=\dfrac{3E}{4}$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
A car engine has an input power of $P_{in}$ and efficiency of $\eta$.  Which of the following gives the wasted energy from the engine in time of $t$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$ $\eta$t
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$ $\dfrac{\eta}{t}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$t - P$_{in}$ $\eta$t
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$t - $\dfrac{\eta}{t}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Useful power output is given by $P_{in}\eta$, so the useful energy is $P_{in}\eta t$.
Input energy is given by $P_{in}t$,
therefore, wasted energy is given by $P_{in} t$ - $P_{in}\eta t$
Therefore the answer is C.
Alternative 2: 
$E_{Waste} = E_T(100\% - \eta) = P_{in}t(1-\eta) = P_{in}t - P_{in}\eta t$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Energy density is defined as the amount of energy stored in a substance per unit volume. Amounts of substances A and B are employed to supply the same average power to a city over an identical time period. The densities of these substances are $\rho$ and $2\rho$, respectively, with their respective volumes being $2V$ and $V$. Consider the following statements:


- I.A greater mass was used than substance BII.It has a lower energy density than substance BIII.It provided the same amount of energy as substance B

Which statement is/are correct for substance A and the amount of it used in the time period?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ III only
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The mass of substances can be determined by multiplying their density and volume, ensuring their masses are equal. Since both substances provide the same average of power over the same time, they provide the same amount of energy. ($E=Pt$)
Energy density can be calculated by


- Energy density = $\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}$

While both provide the same amount of energy, Substance B has a smaller volume compared to Substance A. Consequently, Substance A possesses a lower energy density.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
A boat is traveling along a straight line for a total time of one hour. The boat travels at a constant speed and covers a total distance of 2.4 km. The thrust of the boat's engine is 1.8 kN.
What is the energy exerted by the boat's engine in one second?


- A. $\hspace{1em} $ 0.67 kJ
- B. $\hspace{1em} $ 1.2 kJ
- C. $\hspace{1em} $ 4.3 kJ
- D. $\hspace{1em} $ 78 kJ
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $P = \dfrac{E}{t}$

so energy exerted in one second is the same as power.


- $P = Fv$



- $v = 2.4$ km h$^{-1} = 2.4(1000$ m)(3600 s)$^{-1}$ = $\dfrac{2400\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}} = \dfrac{2}{3}$  m s$^{-1}$



- $P = (1.8$ kN)$\bigg(\dfrac{2}{3}$ m s$^{-1}\bigg)$ = 1.2 kW

Therefore the energy exerted in one second is 1.2 kJ.

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
A box of mass 2.0 kg starts to move on a level surface under the effect of a varying net force $F$. The variation of $F$ with the displacement $s$ of the object is shown in the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4bfc368-0267-49cf-8736-1f84399bfb17/images/203a8d73-301e-4840-b6e9-aede11252de9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.12.14%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the speed of the box at s = 5 m?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $5 m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{5}$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	1$5 m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{15}$ m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The work done $W$ by the $F$ on the box equals the change in kinetic energy $\Delta E_k$ of the box and work done can be found by calculating the area under the graph, the area between the line and the displacement axis.


- $W=\Delta E_k \hspace{2em}$     and   $\hspace{2em} W=$ Area of the graph
- $\Delta E_k=$ Area of the graph (using trapezond formula)
- $\dfrac{1}{2}\left(2\right)v^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+2)(5)$
- $v^2=25$
- $v=5\, $m$\,$s$^{-1}$

Alternatively, we can treat the area as a rectangle and a triangle.


- $\Delta E_k=$ Area of the graph (using rectangle and triangle)
- $\dfrac{1}{2}\left(2\right)v^2=(2)(5)+\dfrac{1}{2}(6)(5)$
- $v^2=25$
- $v=5\, $m$\,$s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
A varying force acts on a spring. The variation of the extension $x$ of the spring with force $F$ acting on it is shown in the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec27ecb3-2d0f-45e3-9076-c10b42685391/images/77ac9eb1-21af-49dc-951a-c2d213bf94cb/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2011.51.09%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $E$ when the extension of the spring is $e$. What is the work done by force on the spring to increase the extension from $e$ to $3e$ ?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  2E$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	4E$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	8E$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	9E$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $E$ when it is stretched by $e$;


- $E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}ke^2$  where $k$ is the spring constant of the spring

The elastic potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched by $3e$ can be found  as;


- $E_{Hfinal}=\dfrac{1}{2}k{(3e)}^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k{9e}^2=9E$

The work done on the spring can be found by calculating the change in the elastic potential energy $\Delta E_H$ of the spring.


- $\mathrm{\Delta}E_H=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(final)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(initial\right)}$
- $\mathrm{\Delta}E_H=9E-E=8E$

Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 27
list.content: While practising, a table tennis player hits a ball of mass 2.8 g that collides with the floor and then bounces back from the wall. The speed of the ball just before reaching the floor is 8.0 m s$^{-1}$. The ball leaves the floor with an angle of 65$\degree$ to the floor as shown. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f046049-9d52-4f31-bdb9-04593858342e/images/33f83956-3349-49c0-b000-e177f8854ee9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.39.45%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Due to the collision with the floor, the ball losses 30$\%$ of its initial kinetic energy. Show that the leaving speed of the ball from the floor is around 7 m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The ball strikes the wall just as it reaches the highest point of its motion. Determine the horizontal distance between the bounce point and the wall. [3] - The ball collides elastically with the wall, with the time of contact during the collision is 0.040 s. Calculate the average horizontal force exerted by the wall on the ball during the collision. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\textrm{Initial\ Kinetic\ Energy}=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({8)}^2=0.090$ J $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v= \sqrt{\dfrac{(0.7)(.090\ )(2)}{(2.8\times{10}^{-3})}}=\answer{6.7\ \ce{m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The kinetic energy $E_{ki}$ just before the collision; $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2$  where $u$ is the speed of the ball just before the collision
  
  
  - $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({8)}^2=0.090$ J

  Since 30$\%$ of the $E_{ki}$ is lost, the final kinetic energy $E_{Kf}$ is
  
  
  - $E_{kf}=\left(0.7\right)\left(0.090\right)=0.063$ J
  - $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$,  where $v$ is the speed of the ball just after the collision
  - $0.063=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({v)}^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(0.063)(2)}{(2.8\times{10}^{-3})}}=6.7$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- Vertically,
  
  
  - $u_y = 6.7\sin(65\degree)$ $\checkmark$
  - $t\ =\ \dfrac{v-u}{a}\ =\ \dfrac{0\ -\ 6.7\sin({65\degree})}{9.8}\ = \ 0.62$ s $\checkmark$

  Horizontally,
  
  
  - $s=vt=6.7\cos({65\degree})\left(0.62\right)=\answer{1.8\ \ce{m}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The ball undergoes projectile motion. The collision with the wall takes place when the ball is at the highest part of its motion, so the vertical component of the motion can be used to find the time of flight.
  
  
  - $u_y = 6.7\sin(65\degree)$ and $y = 0$
  - $t\ =\ \dfrac{v-u}{a}\ =\ \dfrac{0-6.7\sin\left({65\degree}\right)}{9.8}\  =\ 0.62$ s

  Using this time in the horizontal direction, where $u_x = 6.7\cos(65\degree)$
  
  
  - $s=vt=6.7\cos\left({65\degree}\right)\left(0.62\right)=1.8$ m




- $\Delta p = 2mv = 2(0.0028)(6.7\cos(65\degree)) =0.016$ N s $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $F\ =\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}= \dfrac{0.016}{0.040}= \answer{0.40\ \ce{N}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
As the ball rebounds elastically, the final speed is equal to the initial speed.
  These speeds are equal to the horizontal component of the velocity
  
  
  - $v_x=6.7\cos(65\degree) =2.83$ m s$^{-1}$

  To find change in momentum
  $\begin{aligned}
   \Delta p&=p_2-p_1 \\
   &=mv_2-mv_1 \\
   &=0.0028\left(2.83-\left(-2.83\right)\right)
   =0.016\textrm{ N s}
   \end{aligned}$
  Note that because of the change in direction, the change in momentum is equal to twice the initial momentum.
  To find force,
  
  
  
  - $F\ =\ \dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{0.016}{0.040}= 0.40$ N

list.title: Question 28
list.content: An elastic bungee cord of natural length $20$ m is being tested. A spherical object, originally at rest, is released from a platform. Air resistance and the mass of the cord are insignificant. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/08604633-fc44-4b7b-b6e7-ff05446ce89d/PH0644-000.png) - State the principle of conservation of energy. [2] - Describe the energy changes that take place in the spherical object from the time it is released until it comes to rest for the first time. [2] - Show that the speed of the object just before the cord starts to extend is approximately $20$ m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The magnitude of the average $\underline{\textrm{net}}$ force acting on the object between the point where the cord starts to extend and the point where it reaches maximum extension is $360$ N. The time taken during the fall of the object between these points is $0.28$ s. - Show that the mass of the object is approximately $5.0$ kg. [2] - On the graph below, sketch how the the elastic potential energy $E_{H}$ of the spring changes with the vertical displacement $s$ as the cord stretches. There is no need to add values to the axes. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/a3f03b0a-9936-43ec-b0e8-351bd0ef3d31/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.28.03%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - The extension of the cord at the point in time when the object has zero acceleration is $11$ m. Determine the spring constant of the cord. [2]
list.markScheme:
- (in any process) energy is neither created nor destroyed $\checkmark$
  It can only be transformed from one form into another. $\checkmark$
  
- The gravitational potential energy of the object is converted to the kinetic energy of the object. $\checkmark$
  The kinetic and gravitational potential energy of the object are converted into elastic potential energy within the cord. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When it is released, its gravitational potential energy is converted to kinetic energy due to the decrease in height above the ground. As soon as the centre of mass of the object has fallen by $20$ m, the cord starts to extend and store elastic potential energy. As it comes to rest, the object's kinetic and gravitational potential energy are converted to the elastic potential energy of the cord.
  
- 
  
  - $mg \Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$ $\checkmark$
  - $v=\answer{19.8\ \ce{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The decrease in height of the object is $20$ m. Its decrease in gravitational potential energy equals the increase in kinetic energy.
  
  
  - $mg\Delta h= \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{2g\Delta h}$
  - $v=\sqrt{(2)(9.81)(20)}$
  - $v=19.8$ m s$^{-1}$

  Alternatively,
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$
  - $v^2=0^2+2(-9.81)(-20)$
  - $v=19.8$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- 
  - 
    
    - $F_{avg}\Delta t=\Delta p$ $\checkmark$
    - $m = \answer{5.04\ \ce{kg} }\ \checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The object is stationary and has zero momentum when the cord has maximum extension. By using impulse = change in momentum;
    $\begin{aligned}
      F_{avg}\Delta t&=\Delta p\\
      (360)(0.28)&=m(19.8)\\
      100.8&=m(19.8)\\
      m&=\dfrac{100.8}{19.8}\\
      m&=5.09\textrm{ kg}\\
      \end{aligned}$
    
  - $\hspace{2em}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/91a2589c-b619-4d71-90f8-2a7948064acb/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.32.17%E2%80%AF0AM.JPEG)


    Parabolic graph with positive gradient. $\checkmark$
    Passes through origin. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The elastic potential energy stored in the cord is proportional to the square of the extension. Since the force acting on the cord is downwards due to the weight of the object, the vertical displacement of the object s as the cord starts to extend equals the extension x of the cord.
    
    
    - $s^2\propto x^2\propto E_{H}$

    This relationship can be represented by a graph in the shape of
    
    
    - $y=x^2$

    
  - Weight of the object = force of the spring on the object/$W=kx$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $k=\dfrac{W}{x} = \dfrac{49}{11}$
    - $k=\answer{4.5\ \ce{ N m}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The forces acting on the object are the weight of the object and the force of spring on the object. When the object has no acceleration, these two forces are balanced by each other. The weight of the object;
    
    
    - $W=mg=\left(5.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=49$ N

    By using Hooke's Law:
    
    
    - $F=kx$
    - $k=\dfrac{F}{x}$
    - $k=\dfrac{49}{11}$
    - $k=4.5$ N m$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
A natural gas plant burns fuel with a specific energy of 80 MJ kg$^{-1}$.
The rate of energy input of the natural gas is 1.6 GW. What is the rate at which the fuel burns?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.0005 kg s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 kg s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 1500 kg s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 20 kg s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The energy delivered per second (power) will be equal to the product of the mass burning rate and the specific energy.
Therefore,


- $\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}(80\textrm{ MJ kg}^{-1})=1.6$ GW
- $\dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{1.6\times10^9\textrm{ J s}^{-1}}{8.0\times10^7\textrm{ J kg}^{-1}}=20$ kg s$^{-1}$

list.title: Question 30
list.content: - Define momentum. [1] - A golf ball of mass 45 g moving with a constant velocity of 2.0 m s$^{-1}$ undergoes a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 2.0 kg. The line that joins the centres of the balls is along the direction of the velocity of the golf ball. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/a31f1159-d99f-4baa-a497-a3dd8fb09c8a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Use Newton's Third Law and Second Law to deduce why the change in momentum of the golf ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the stationary ball during the collision. [3] - The variation of force acting on the golf ball $F$ with the time $t$ during the collision is shown in the graph. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/56c450d9-aa69-4205-b5b8-66efcaaa540a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.05.14%E2%80%AFPM.png) Show that the magnitude of the change in momentum of the golf ball is approximately 0.09 kg m s$^{-1}$. [2] - Calculate the speed of the golf ball just after the collision. [3] - Discuss whether the collision is elastic or inelastic. [4]
list.markScheme:
- The product of mass and velocity. $\checkmark$



- 
  - According to Newton's third Law, the force acting on the golf ball equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball/$F_g=-F_s$ $\checkmark$
    According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum/$\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$ $\checkmark$
    Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions/ since $\Delta t$ for each ball is equal, $\Delta p_g=-\Delta p_s$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to Newton's third law, the force acting on the golf ball $F_g$ equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball $F_s$ during the collision.
    
    
    - $F_g=-F_s$

    According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum. Therefore, the rate of change in momentum of the ball $\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}$   equals and is opposite to the rate of change of momentum in the stationary ball $\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$.
    
    
    - $\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$

    Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions.
    
  - Area under the graph = impulse / change in momentum $\checkmark$
    change in momentum = $\dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3}) = \answer{0.086\ \textrm{kg m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$ (extra significant figures must be shown to receive full marks)
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the “Force acting on the object” “Time of acting force” graph equals the impulse and also the change in momentum. Therefore, the area of the triangle $A_t$ should be calculated to get the change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    $\begin{aligned}
     \Delta p &= A_t\\
      &= \dfrac{1}{2}bh\\ 
      &= \dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3})\\
      &=0.086\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}
      \end{aligned}$
    
  - Use of $\Delta p=mv-mu$ $\checkmark$
    $-0.086=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)$ $\checkmark$ (negative sign on change in momentum must be seen)
    $v=\ll \dfrac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}\gg= \answer{0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$
    Note: Use of 0.09 kg m s$^{-1}$ gives a final speed of 0 m s$^{-1}$. This is accepted if full working is shown.
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force acting on the golf ball during the collision is towards the left. Hence, the change in momentum of the golf ball must be towards the left. When left is chosen as negative and right is chosen as positive for the vectors, the following relationship can be written for change in momentum;
    $\Delta p=mv-mu$ where $\Delta p=-0.086$ kg m s$^{-1}$, $m=45\times10^{-3}$ kg, $u=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$, and $v=$ final velocity after the collision.
    $\begin{aligned}
     -0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     (90 \times 10^{-3})-0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     4 \times 10^{-3}&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     \frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}&=v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v
     \end{aligned}$
    
  - Kinetic energy before the collision = $\dfrac{1}{2}m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090$ J $\checkmark$
    Change in momentum of larger ball = 0.086 N s
    
    
    - $p = mv$
    - $0.086=2.0v$

    Speed of the stationary ball after the collision $=0.043\,\ce{m s}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    Correct calculation of final total kinetic energy according to the result of (b)(iii)
    
    
    - $E_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+ \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2=0.0020$ J
    - $0.0020$ J $\checkmark$

    Kinetic energy after is less so the collision is inelastic. $\checkmark$
    Note: A calculation leading to the kinetic energy after being equal to the kinetic energy before and a statement that the collision is elastic would score only one mark total.
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The total kinetic energy of the balls before the collision $E_{tkb}$ equals the kinetic energy of the golf ball before the collision $E_{kgb}$;
    
    
    - $E_{tkb}=E_{kgb}=\dfrac{1}{2} m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090$ J

    The speed of the stationary ball after the collision can be found by
    $\Delta p=mv-mu$ where $\Delta p=0.086$ kg m s$^{-1}$, $m=2.0$ kg, $u=0$ m s$^{-1}$
    
    
    - $\begin{aligned}
       \ 0.086 &=2.0v\\
       \ \frac{0.086}{2.0}&= v\\
       \ 0.043\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v\\
       \end{aligned}$

    The total kinetic energy of the balls after the collision $E_{tka}$ equals the sum of the kinetic energy of the golf $E_{kga}$ and stationary balls $E_{ksa}$ after the collision;
    
    
    - $\begin{aligned}
       E_{tka}&=E_{kga}+E_{ksa}\\
       &=\frac{1}{2} m_g v_g^2+\frac{1}{2} m_s v_s^2\\
       &=\frac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+\frac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2\\
       &=0.0020\textrm{ J}
       \end{aligned}$

    $E_{tkb}>E_{tka}$, the kinetic energy of the systems is not conserved. Therefore, collision is inelastic.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
A car is moving with a kinetic energy of ${10}^5$ J.
Estimate the order of magnitude of its momemtum.


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^3$ kg m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^4$ kg m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^5$ kg m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	{10}^6$ kg m s$^{-1}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The relationship between kinetic energy $E_k$ and momentum $p$ of the car is given by the following formula:


- $E_k=\dfrac{p^2}{2m}$
- $p^2=2mE_k$

The order of magnitude of the mass of a car is ${10}^3\, kg$.


- $p^2\approx 2\left({10}^3\right)\left({10}^5\right)$
- $p^2\approx{10}^8 $
- $p\approx{10}^4$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
A spring of spring constant $200$ N m$^{-1}$ is compressed by $6.0$ cm. A box is placed against the spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3624b206-05d4-4c78-b7ce-8a72357800ac/images/750688b5-572c-4f91-ba5f-bb29977761fa/Screenshot%202025-07-04%20at%201.23.34%E2%80%AFPM.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}$
At the point where the box has moved 4.0 cm, how much work has been done by the spring on the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	0.16$ J
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	0.20$ J
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	0.32$ J
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	0.36$ J
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The work done by the spring on the box equals to decrease in elastic potential energy $\mathrm{\Delta}E_H$ of the spring. The initial compression of the spring is $6$ cm and the final compression of the spring is $2.0$ cm due to a $4.0$ cm displacement.
$\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H(initial)}-\mathrm{\Delta}E_{H\left(final\right)}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\frac{1}{2}\left(200\right)\left({0.06}^2\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(200\right)\left({0.02}^2\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=(100)\left({{0.06}^2-\ 0.02}^2\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\mathrm{\Delta}E_H&=\left(100\right) \bigg(\frac{36-4}{10000}\bigg)=0.32 \textrm{ J}\ \
\end{aligned}$
Therefore, the answer is C.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
The engine of a car exerts a constant driving force as the car accelerates from rest along a straight horizontal road. Friction and air resistance are negligible. Which of the following graphs shows how the power of the engine $P$ varies with distance traveled by the car $s$?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/63372b4f-5716-4339-8b66-882283cf92b4/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.18%E2%80%AFAM.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/96b2c4f9-dac1-41fa-9bd8-be6fefb7b546/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.23%E2%80%AFAM.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/5bfae98b-84b2-4180-9db5-f6759bd83290/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.28%E2%80%AFAM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/e66290cc-6d6b-4620-b582-d97535073873/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.32%E2%80%AFAM.png)
list.markScheme:
A
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $P=Fv$

Force is constant so $P\propto v$.
Constant force implies constant acceleration. So, we may use the equations for constant acceleration (suvat).


- $v^2=u^2+2as$

The car starts from rest so


- $v^2=2as$

Given that $a$ is constant we can say


- $v^2 \propto s$
- $v \propto \sqrt{s}$

So as $s$ increases $v$ increases at a decreasing rate.


- $P \propto v \propto \sqrt{s}$

Therefore


- $P \propto \sqrt{s}$

So as $s$ increases $P$ increases at a decreasing rate and the graph will take the shape of a square-root curve.

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
An object is thrown vertically upwards on the surface of the moon. The maximum height that the object can reach is $h$. When the object reaches the height of  $\dfrac{h}{3}$ above the surface, what is the ratio

$\hspace{3cm} \dfrac{\textrm{Kinetic\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }{\textrm{Gravitational\ potential\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }$



- A. $\hspace{1em} 1 $
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{2}{3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3}{2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  2$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since there is no atmosphere on the moon, energy is not lost to the surroundings due to air resistance. At the highest position of the object, all of the kinetic energy will have been converted to gravitational potential energy $E_t$.
Thus the total energy of the object:


- $E_t=mgh$

where $mg$ is the weight of the object.
The total energy at $\dfrac{h}{3}$ should be the sum of the kinetic $E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$ and the gravitational potential energy of the object $E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$.


- $E_t=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$
- $mgh=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+mg\dfrac{h}{3}$
- $mg\dfrac{2h}{3}=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$

Therefore


- $\dfrac{E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}{E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}=\dfrac{mg\frac{2h}{3}}{mg\frac{h}{3}}=2$

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
A tennis ball with mass $60$ g travels horizontally with constant speed $u$. The ball hits a stationary racket and rebounds in the opposite direction with a horizontal speed $v$. The time for the collision is $5.0$ ms.
What is the magnitude of the average force on the ball?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $0.06(u-v)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $0.06(u+v)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $12(u-v)$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $12(u+v)$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
$\hspace{1em}$ $F\Delta t=\Delta p$
$\hspace{1em}$ $F=\dfrac{m(\Delta v)}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{(60 \times 10^{-3})\left ((-v)-u \right )}{5 \times 10^{-3}}=-12(u+v)$
The magnitude of the force is
$F=12(u+v)$
Note that because there is a change in direction and the velocities are treated as vectors, we add the magnitudes of the starting and finishing velocities to find the change in velocity.

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
A motorised toy car starts from rest, with the motor delivering increasing power to the car over time as shown in the graph below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ec6c266e-9dfb-4ac7-9e6b-2eb4858fef0e/images/9e9d2002-d57d-423c-b80e-9ad472b32f71/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%209.08.04%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Assuming no energy losses, which of the following gives the kinetic energy of the car after 8.0 seconds?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.20 J
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5.0 J
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 160 J
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 320 J
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The energy can be found by calculating the area under the graph.


- Work done = $\dfrac{(Power)(time)}{2}$
- $W = \dfrac{(40\textrm{ W})(8\textrm{ s})}{2} = 160$ J


Alternative solution:
Because Power increases at a constant rate, the average Power ($P_{av}$) can be found from the average of the starting and ending powers.


- $P_{av} = \dfrac{0+40}{2} = 20$ W
- $E=P_{av}t = (20)(8) = 160$ J

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
A ball with mass $m$ is released from a height of $h$ and undergoes free fall. The ball hits the ground and rebounds vertically. On rebound, the ball reaches a maximum height of $h'$. The time taken for the collision is $T$. During the collision, what are the change in kinetic energy of the ball and the magnitude of the average net force on the ball?

$\hspace{1em}$ Change in kinetic energy $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1em}$ Average force $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h-h')$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h'-h)$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h'-h)$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h-h')$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in kinetic energy  = Loss of mechanical energy = change in potential energy


- = $mgh' - mgh = mg(h'-h)$

We can find the velocity before hitting the ground using conservation of energy


- $\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2=mgh$

giving


- $u = \sqrt{2gh}$

Similarly, velocity after bouncing from the ground


- $v = - \sqrt{2gh'}$

Change in momentum


- $\Delta p = m (v-u)$ = $m (-\sqrt{2gh'} - \sqrt{2gh})$

Force is rate of change of momentum


- $F_{av} = \dfrac{-m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$

Because the question asks for the magnitude of the average force, we can take the positive value.


- $F_{av} = \dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
A motor uses a cable to pull a trolley up an inclined plane at a constant velocity.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/03c2e4aa-9eff-4287-8eef-0ae906343fba/images/28f10955-8ba2-42e6-b8d5-59a2eaf0a440/ph0035q.JPEG)


Consider the following statements about the energy changes of the trolley during its motion.


- I.The work done by the engine has greater magnitude than the work done by friction.II.The total of kinetic and potential energy of the trolley increases.III.The gain in gravitational potential energy of the trolley has the same magnitude as the work done by the engine.

Of the statements above, which is/are correct?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
I.	Correct: as the trolley moves up gravitational potential energy increases so work done by the trolley is done against both friction and gravity.
II.	Correct: kinetic energy is constant since trolley is moving at constant velocity but gravitational potential energy increases as height of it from ground increases.
III.	Incorrect: some amount of work done by the engine is used to increase gravitational potential energy, but some of it wasted as work done by friction.

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
A ball is released from rest at a height $h$ above the ground. At each bounce 75% of its kinetic energy is lost. Which graph represents the variation of the ball's velocity $v$ with time $t$ from the beginning of motion until the moment just before the third bounce? Assume the acceleration of the ball is in in the negative direction and that air resistance is negligible.

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/a516a5f2-3a03-4885-811d-0da67b6ad48e/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.14%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/c52e4b88-650f-407b-aa7e-ecf2ab94b5f1/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.26%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/f9d6effd-a838-49ed-b769-1e65f233ace2/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/75cb8fb0-e10e-4e0e-b129-422f1813f50d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Kinetic energy $E_k$ is directly proportional to the square of the magnitude of velocity $v$


- $E_k = \dfrac{1}{2} mv^2$

The velocity will decrease to half of its value at each bounce.
The value of the acceleration is constant, free fall acceleration $g$. The velocity time graph should be linear and all sections should have a negative gradient to represent downwards acceleration.
The direction of velocity is positive on the way up, and negative on the way down.

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
A box of mass $2$ kg is pushed with an initial speed of 10 m s$^{-1}$ on a rough horizontal floor. A uniform frictional force of $10$ N acts on the box. What is the distance travelled by the box at the instant when the kinetic energy of the box is halved?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 2 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 1 m
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The loss of kinetic energy is equal to half of the orinal kinetic energy:


- $E_{k(Lost)}= \dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2}$

Work done by friction is equal to the loss of kinetic energy.


- $E_{k(Lost)} = W = F_fs$
- $\dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2} = F_fs$

By substituting given values in the equation using $E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) \dfrac{(2)(10^2)}{2}  &= 10\,s\\
\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(100) &= 10\,s\\
50 &= 10\,s\\
s &= 5 
\end{aligned}$
Therefore, the answer is B.

list.title: Question 41
list.content: - Define power. [2] - A mass of 2.0 kg is pulled by a variable horizontal force $F$ on a smooth surface. A thread attached to the mass passes over an ideal pulley and supports another mass of 3.0 kg. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6d2978a2-8915-43ea-81e8-b90f69b8cfdb/images/54a24a36-45c5-41c8-88ac-6404e8c6a27d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%202.02.26%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) The variation of $F$ with the distance moved $s$ by the mass of 2.0 kg is shown in the graph. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6d2978a2-8915-43ea-81e8-b90f69b8cfdb/images/396463b0-f97b-4b81-bbff-13f146be2570/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.54.070%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Calculate work done, in J, on the 2.0 kg mass by the force $F$ when the mass travelled 0.90 m. [2] - Calculate the final speed of the 2.0 kg mass. [3] - On another occasion, the horizontal force is no longer applied and the 2.0 kg mass is replaced with a motor which pulls the 3.0 kg mass with a constant speed of 0.50 m s$^{-1}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6d2978a2-8915-43ea-81e8-b90f69b8cfdb/images/68054dc2-3d77-46ce-913a-f9e4731f2b2d/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%202.04.50%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - On the graph, show the variation of the change in gravitational potential energy $\Delta E_p$ of the mass with time $t$. [2] (no need to add values to the axes) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6d2978a2-8915-43ea-81e8-b90f69b8cfdb/images/6048a61c-c1e7-414f-8cb0-552bca553acf/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%204.44.21%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - The power supplied to the motor is 20 W. Calculate the efficiency of the motor. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Rate of $\checkmark$
  Energy transfer/work done $\checkmark$
  (accept work/change in energy $\checkmark$ divided by time taken for the change $\checkmark$)
  
- 
  - Area=work done $\checkmark$
    $\ll (40)(0.9) + 0.5(120)(0.9) = \gg$ $90$ J
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area of the force-distance graph gives work done by the force when the force is parallel to the direction of motion. The area can be calculated by dividing it into two subsections; a rectangle and a triangle. The area of the rectangle $A_r$;
    
    
    - $A_r=(0.9)(40)=36$

    The area of the triangle $A_t$;
    
    
    - $A_t=(0.5)(0.9)(120)=54$

    When they are added,
    
    
    - $36+54=90$ J

    
  - Increase in gravitational potential energy of the system/$\Delta E_p = (3.0)(9.81)(0.9) = 26$ J $\checkmark$
    $90-26=64\,\checkmark$
    $\ll 64 = \frac{1}{2}(2.0)v^2 + \frac{1}{2}(3.0)v^2 = 2.5v^2 \gg$
    $\ll v = \sqrt{\dfrac{63.5}{2.5}} = \gg$ $5.0$ m s$^{-1}$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When force is applied to the mass, it accelerates. This increases its and the other mass's speed. Additionally, the other mass is pulled upward. Therefore, the energy supplied to the system by work done should be used as an increase in the kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy of the system.
    The kinetic energy increase in the system $\Delta E_K$;
    
    
    - $\Delta E_K = \Delta E_{Kmass\,of\,2\,kg} + \Delta E_{Kmass\,of\,3\,kg}$
    - $\Delta E_K = \frac{1}{2}(2.0)v^2 + \frac{1}{2}(3.0)v^2 = 2.5v^2$  where $v$ is the common speed of the masses

    The mass of 2.0 kg does not change its vertical position. Therefore, an increase in gravitational potential energy happens only for the mass of 3.0 kg. The increase in gravitational potential energy $\Delta E_p$;
    
    
    - $\Delta E_p = mgh$ where $m = 3.0$ kg and $h = 0.9$ m
    - $\Delta E_p = (3.0)(9.81)(0.9) = 26.5$ J

    The energy is used for the increase in kinetic energy;
    
    
    - $\Delta E_K = W - \Delta E_p = 90 - 26.5 = 63.5$ J

    Therefore
    
    
    - $2.5v^2 = 63.5$
    - $v^2 = 25.4$
    - $v=5.0$ m s$^{-1}$

    

- 
  - $\textrm{ }$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6d2978a2-8915-43ea-81e8-b90f69b8cfdb/images/3f707080-5bf4-4b8a-98cd-cf88904e33cf/PHG0460c.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with GeoGebra by Tom Walsh- https://www.geogebra.org/m/jrWMapS7]}}$
    A straight line $\checkmark$
    passing through the origin $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The change in gravitational potential energy $\Delta E_p$ of the mass;
    
    
    - $\Delta E_p = mgh$

    Since the mass is moving with constant speed, $h$ can be expressed as
    
    
    - $h = vt$ where $v$ is the speed of the mass

    When it is substituted into the previous expression;
    
    
    - $\Delta E_p = mgvt$ where $m$, $g$ and $v$ are constant

    Therefore, the change in gravitational potential energy and time should be directly proportional. This relationship can be shown on the graph with a straight line passing through the origin.
    
  - Power is delivered to the mass = $(29)(0.50) = 15$ W $\checkmark$
    $\ll$ Efficiency = $\dfrac{Power\,out}{Power\,in} \times 100\% = \dfrac{14.72}{20} \times 100\% = \gg$ $74\%$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The power delivered $P_D$ by the motor is used for pulling the mass of 3 kg. It can be calculated as;
    $P_D = Fv$ where $F$ is the force on the mass due to tension and $v$ is the speed of the mass
    Since the mass is moving with constant speed, tension $F$ must be balancing the weight of the object $W$.
    
    
    - $F = W = mg = (3.0)(9.81) = 29$ N

    So, the power is delivered to the mass;
    
    
    - $P_D = Fv = (29)(0.50) = 15$ W
    - Efficiency = $\dfrac{Power\,out}{Power\,in} \times 100\% = \dfrac{14.72}{20} \times 100\% = 74\%$

list.title: Question 42
list.content: - The diagram below shows a water slide. As a test, an object is released from point A, 6.0 m above the ground level. Point B at the end of the slide is 2.0 m above the ground level. Location C is the point of contact of the slide with the ground. The slide approximates a circular shape at this point. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/86876d63-7070-4138-84e3-625f77cab51c/images/ac8ba796-8e18-4784-8178-2f7f2de2ab2a/PH0617.png) Air resistance and friction on the object are negligible. - Draw the free-body diagram of the forces acting on the object as it passes point D. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/86876d63-7070-4138-84e3-625f77cab51c/images/b491ee9e-6016-4ca8-bbdc-29dbe236431a/PH0617q2.png) - At the instant the object passes point C, explain why there is acceleration and yet no work is done. [2] - The object slides from point A to point B and is launched from point B with an angle. - Show that the speed of the object at point $B$ is approximately $8.9$ m s$^{-1}$ [2] - At point B, the object is launched into the air and lands in a pool of water that is 2.2 m below point B. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/86876d63-7070-4138-84e3-625f77cab51c/images/fada1d61-dc23-4337-b9eb-a068336066c1/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.52.08%E2%80%AFPM.png) After 1.1 s, it reaches the surface of the water. Show that the angle $\theta$ of the launch above the horizontal is approximately 22$\degree$. [3] - Calculate the horizontal distance travelled by the object between losing contact with the slide and reaching the water. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\hspace{1em}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/86876d63-7070-4138-84e3-625f77cab51c/images/6c1c11cb-7645-4839-a9b1-9a1d5b112e8b/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%204.36.32%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


    Correct directions of forces with correct labels $\checkmark$
    The weight vector is longer than the reaction force $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Two forces are acting on the box. Since the box is accelerating down to the slope, the resultant force should be down the slope. The component of the weight that is perpendicular to the incline must be balanced by the normal force. The other component of the weight is the force that creates acceleration. Therefore, the weight should be greater than the normal force. It can be represented with a longer arrow for weight.
    
  - Acceleration is only a change in direction $\checkmark$
    The resultant force is perpendicular to the direction of the motion $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
There is a change in direction of the box, therefore there is acceleration and there must be a non-zero resultant force.
    In uniform circular motion, the resultant force is perpendicular to the direction of the motion.
    The work done is:
    
    
    - $W=Fd\cos(\theta)$,

    where $\theta$ is the angle between the direction of the motion and the force
    Since $\theta=90\degree$, $\cos(90\degree)=0$.
    Therefore the work done is zero.
    

- 
  - 
    
    - $mg\Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 \ \checkmark$
    - $v=$ $8.86$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
By using energy conservation between points $A$ and $B$:
    $\begin{aligned}
    E_{P\ at\ 6\ m}&=E_{P\ at\ 2\ m}+E_K\\
    mgh_6 &= mgh_2 +\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\\
    m\left(9.81\right)\left(6.0\right)&=m\left(9.81\right)\left(2.0\right)+\frac{1}{2}mv^2\\
    \left(9.81\right)\left(6.0\right)&=\left(9.81\right)\left(2.0\right)+\frac{1}{2}v^2\\
    \sqrt{\left(39.2\right)\left(2\right)}&=v\\
    v&=8.86\textrm{ m s}^{-1}
    \end{aligned}$
  - Use of $u=8.9\sin\theta$ and $s=-2.2\textrm{ m}$ $\checkmark$
    $-2.2=\left(8.9\right)\left(\sin\theta\right)\left(1.1\right)+\dfrac{1}{2}\left(-9.81\right)\left(1.1\right)^2$ $\checkmark$
    $\theta=\answer{22.3\degree}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The launch speed of the box is $8.9$ m s$^{-1}$. The vertical displacement $s$ of the box to reach the surface of the water is -2.2 m. The vertical component of the launch velocity $u$:
    
    
    - $u=8.9\sin\theta$

    By using uniform acceleration  equations, the following relationship can be written:
    $\begin{aligned}
     s\ &=ut+\frac{1}{2}at^2\\
     -2.2\ &=\left(8.9\sin\theta\right)\left(1.1\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(-9.81\right)\left(1.1\right)^2\\
     5.9-2.2\ &=\left(8.9\sin\theta\right)\left(1.1\right)\\
     \frac{3.7}{\left(8.9\right)\left(1.1\right)}&=\sin\theta \\
     0.38\ &=\sin\theta\\
     22.3\degree &=\theta
     \end{aligned}$
    
  - Horizontal component of the launch velocity = $8.9 \cos22=8.3$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $d=\left(8.3\right)\left(1.1\right)$ =       $9.1$ m $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The horizontal component of the launch velocity $u_h$;
    
    
    - $u_h=8.9 \cos22$
    - $u_h=8.3$ m s$^{-1}$

    Since the horizontal speed is constant, the distance travelled $d$;
    
    
    - $d=ut$
    - $d=\left(8.3\right)\left(1.1\right)=9.1$ m

list.title: Question 43
list.content: - In a game, players try to hit a moving cart by projecting a ball at an angle from a spring-loaded launcher. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5d2f365-cfa8-4f39-a985-deee47a8af8e/images/4a39a38c-689e-4257-bf0e-eadef77b444f/PH0845aaaa.png) When the spring is fully uncompressed, it extends to the open end of the barrel. The frictional forces acting on the ball are negligible. - State the main energy changes taking place when the ball is moving inside the barrel. [2] - The following data is available: Mass of the ball: $0.065$ kg The compression of the spring before release: $0.22$ m The spring constant: $10$ N m$^{-1}$ Show that the launch speed of the ball at the end of the barrel is approximately $2.3$ m s$^{-1}$. [3] - When launching the ball, the spring applies a force for $0.022$ s. Determine the average net force acting on the ball during this time interval. [2] - One competitor aligned the launcher at $30\degree$ above the horizontal. At the instant the ball left the launcher, it was $1.25$ m directly above the front of a moving cart which was moving at a steady speed of $2.1$ m s$^{-1}$ directly away from the launcher. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5d2f365-cfa8-4f39-a985-deee47a8af8e/images/786965a2-e660-4483-abe7-61bf392ab47f/PH0845aaa1.png) - Show that the time taken for the ball to displace $1.25$ m vertically downward after leaving the barrel is around $0.64$ s. [3] - The length of the cart is $35$ cm Deduce whether or not the ball will hit the top of the cart. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Elastic potential energy decreases $\checkmark$
Gravitation potential energy and kinetic energy increase $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The spring-ball system stores elastic potential energy. Upon releasing the ball, both its speed and altitude experience an increase. Consequently, this energy is converted into the ball's gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy.
    
  - $\hspace{1.8em}$ $\Delta h = \left ( \Delta x \right ) \left(sin30 \right) = \dfrac{0.22}{2} =$ :0.11 m $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2)}{2} = \dfrac{0.065(v)^2}{2} + (0.065)(9.8)(0.11)$ $\checkmark$
    - $v = \sqrt{\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2) - (2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)}{0.065}} = \answer{2.3} \ll \ce{m s}^{-1} \gg $

    Allow two marks if gravitational potential energy is not considered and the answer 2.7 is obtained.
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The increase in vertical position $\Delta h$ of the ball during the launch:
    
    
    - $\Delta h = (\Delta x)(\sin30) = \dfrac{0.22}{2} = 0.11$ m

    During the launch, the elastic potential energy lost is equal to the gains in gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy:
    
    
    - $\Delta E_{H} = \Delta E_k + \Delta E_p$
    - $\dfrac{k \Delta x^2}{2} = \dfrac{mv^2}{2} + mg \dfrac{\Delta x}{2}$

    By substituting given values:
    
    
    - $\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2)}{2} = \dfrac{0.065(v)^2}{2} + (0.065)(9.8)(0.11)$
    - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(10)(0.22^2) - (2)(0.065)(9.8)(0.11)}{0.065}}=2.3$ m s$^{-1}$

    

- The magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball $= m \Delta v= 0.150$ kg m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{0.15}{0.022}=$     $6.8$ N $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The change in momentum $\Delta p$ of the ball:
  
  
  - $\Delta p = mv = (0.065)(2.3)=0.150$ kg m s$^{-1}$

  Using impulse, we can find the average force $F$ acting on the ball during the interval:
  
  
  - $F = \dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{0.150}{0.022} = 6.79$ N




- 
  - The magnitude of the vertical component of the initial velocity $= 1.15$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    Vertical velocity at the level of the cart $= 5.1$ m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $t=\dfrac{v-u}{a}=\dfrac{(-5.1-1.15)}{-9.81}=$       $0.64$ s $\checkmark$

    OR
    
    
    - $-1.25=1.15t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.81)t^2=$       $0.64$ s $\checkmark$

    Accept alternative usage of uniform acceleration equations
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The magnitude of the vertical component of the initial velocity $v_{0v}$:
    
    
    - $v_{0v} = 2.3\ \sin30 = 1.15$ m s$^{-1}$

    Using the uniform acceleration equations in multiple steps:
    The velocity $v_f$ of the ball when it is displaced at $1.25$ m downwards.
    
    
    - $v_f ^2 = v_i ^2 + 2as$
    - $v_f ^2 = 1.15^2 + (2)(-9.81)(-1.25) = -5.1$ m s$^{-1}$
    - $v_f = -5.1$ m s$^{-1}$

    The time $t$ of the motion:
    
    
    - $v = u + at$
    - $t = \dfrac{v - u}{a} = \dfrac{-5.1 - 1.15}{-9.81} = 0.64$ s

    Alternative method:
    
    
    - $s = v_{0v}t + \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$

    where $s$ is $-1.25$ m, $a$ is $-9.81$ m s$^{-2}$ and $v_{0v}$ is $1.15$ m s$^{-1}$
    
    
    - $-1.25 = 1.15t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.81)t^2$

    Solving using the quadratic formula gives the positive root
    
    
    - $t = 0.64$ s

    
  - Horizontal displacement of the ball = $v_h t=(2.3\cos(30\degree))(0.64)=(1.99)(0.64) =1.27$ m $\checkmark$
    Front of the cart moves $s = vt = (2.1)(0.64) =1.35$ m $\checkmark$
    The front of the cart moves $0.07$ m further than the ball and the cart is $35$ cm long, so the ball hits the cart $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The magnitude of the horizontal component of the initial velocity $v_{0_h}$:
    
    
    - $v_{0_h}=2.3\cos30=1.99$ m s$^{-1}$

    The horizontal displacement $s_h$ of the ball as it displaced $1.25$ m vertically downward:
    $\hspace{1em}$ $s_h = v_{0_h}t = (1.99)(0.64) = 1.28$ m
    The horizontal displacement $s_{hc}$ of any part of the cart:
    
    
    - $s_{h_c} = vt =(2.1)(0.64) = 1.35$ m

    Comparing the numbers and knowing that the cart is $0.35$ m long, the ball with hit the cart, $1.35 - 1.28 = 0.07$ m behind the front of the cart.

list.title: Question 44
list.content: A box half filled with sand is pulled by a motor at a constant speed of $2.0$ m s$^{-1}$ on a frictionless surface. During the motion, sand is added to the box from above at a constant rate of $\sigma$ kg s$^{-1}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e91a12f8-310f-42b8-a135-30c0ad0e892e/images/fb1ec50a-d277-4d69-95d5-266cdd06f303/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.45.240%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - State the condition related to the mass of an object in order for the equation $F_{net}=ma$ to be equivalent to the equation $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}$ . [1] - The force applied by the motor on the box is $0.11$ N. Determine $\sigma$. [2] - The motor has an efficiency of 75%. Calculate the total power provided to the motor. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Mass of the object should be constant $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum
  
  
  - $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}$

  Therefore $F_{net}$ can depend on the rate of change of mass or the rate of change of velocity or both.
  The equation
  
  
  - $F=ma$

  is equivalent to
  
  
  - $F=m\dfrac{\Delta v}{t}$

  and therefore assumes that mass is constant and that only velocity is changing with time.
  
- 
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ $\checkmark$
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}= $ $0.055\textrm{ kg s}^{-1}$  $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force $F$ applied to the box;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$

  Since $v$ is constant;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{v\Delta m}{t}$

  When $\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$ is replaced with $\sigma$;
  
  
  - $F=v\sigma$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ where $F=0.11$ N and $v=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$

  
  
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}=0.055$ kg s$^{-1}$




- Useful power output of the motor $=\ll Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=\gg 0.22$ W $\checkmark$
  The power provided to the motor $=\ll \dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = \gg $  0.29 W $ \checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The useful power output $P_o$ of the motor;
  
  
  - $P_o=Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=0.22$ W

  The efficiency of the motor;
  
  
  - Efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Input power}} \times 100\%$

  So the input power;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Efficiency}} \times 100\%$

  Substitute the given and calculated values;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = 0.29\,W$

list.title: Question 45
list.content: A cannonball is fired horizontally from a cannon positioned at the edge of a cliff. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/075709d5-6b82-4c14-84e3-4e295554dd8f/images/a8bab8c2-0aad-4a4d-8b10-7371910c8ac9/PH0562zzz.png) - In the context of Newton's Laws, explain why the cannon recoils to the left when the cannonball is fired. [2] - The initial recoil speed of the cannon is $1.0$ m s$^{-1}$ and its mass is 1200 kg. - After the ball is fired, the cannon rolls to the left and experiences a resistive force of $8.0$ kN as it rolls. Determine the distance covered by the cannon. [2] - The mass of the cannonball is $9.0$ kg. Show that the magnitude of the velocity of the ball after being fired is approximately $133$ m s$^{-1}$. [2] - Calculate the magnitude of the displacement of the cannonball after $5.0$ s. Air resistance can be ignored. [3]
list.markScheme:
- By Newton's 3rd law, there is a force to the right acting on the cannonball $\checkmark$
  There is an equal and opposite force (to the left) on the cannon $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
There is a force acting on the cannonball during the firing. According to Newton's third law, there must be an equal and opposite force on the cannon.



-
